section.title: Features added and issues fixed in this release
section.para: Following is a list of new and noteworthy features and bug fixes in this release:

listitem.para: JBIDE-6041: When creating a BIRT report that included the EnumType property, an error would be generated. This bug has been corrected by modifying the DataTypes.java file.

JBIDE-7025: OpenOn support has been added for the beans.xml editor. OpenOn support allows you to easily navigate around your project without the use of the Package Explorer or Project Explorer. This is achieved by using the class and method names in your code as links to those code segments.
JBIDE-6998: The Weld project extensions (beans_1_1.xsd) are now supported by the beans.xml editor.

JBIDE-6983: The beans.xml editor now correctly supports elements in other namespaces. This has been achieved by supporting any child element of the <beans> root element and providing dynamic extensions to beans.xml in order to support different namespaces.

JBIDE-6742 and JBIDE-6743: Error messages have been rewritten to clarify the error that occurred. For example, the error message Session bean with a parameterized bean class declares any scope other than @Dependent has been rewritten to say Session bean with a parameterized bean class must have @Dependent scope. For a list of all error messages affected view the associated JIRAs.

JBIDE-6728: Each field injection point that includes an Event type is now provided with a default bean. For example the injection field @Inject @Any @Tame @Role("Master") Event<TamingCommand> tamingEvent will now have a bean for injection.

JBIDE-6704: It is now possible to enable and disable the CDI validator at the project level. To enable project validator settings navigate to ProjectPropertiesCDI SettingsValidatorEnable project specific settings.

JBIDE-6642: Validation has been added to ensure that @Stereotype annotation has the following annotation components: @Target({TYPE, METHOD, FIELD}), @Target(TYPE), @Target(METHOD), @Target(FIELD) or @Target({METHOD, FIELD}), and @Retention(RUNTIME).
JBIDE-6641 and JBIDE-6640: The OpenOn menu for injection points has been upgraded to present more information concerning eligible beans and indicates the class or classes that will be injected.
JBIDE-6639: Validation has been added to ensure that @Scope and @NormalScope annotation have the following annotation components: @Target({TYPE, METHOD, FIELD}) and @Retention(RUNTIME).

JBIDE-6637: Validation has been added to ensure that @Qualifier and @NormalScope annotation have the following annotation components: @Target({METHOD, FIELD, PARAMETER, TYPE}) and @Retention(RUNTIME).

JBIDE-6636: Errors in the @Typed annotation applied to the Bean class, Producer method and the Producer field were not reported on. If @Typed annotation errors are present in these circumstances, the errors are now reported to the user.

JBIDE-6635: A bug existed that would ignore the decorator of a class and take a user straight to the bean when choosing the Open Injected Class option. This issue has been corrected by expanding on the list of options to choose from. New options include Open Decorator NAME and Open Interceptor NAME

JBIDE-6574 and JBIDE-6505: The Java Specification Request 299 (JSR-299) specifies context and dependency injection for the Java EE platform. To cater for this more than 70 validation rules have been added that reference the specific section of the JSR-299 specification each validation error relates to. This functionality ensures that written annotations will compile correctly.
JBIDE-6523: Validation has been added for all classes and annotation names.

JBIDE-6446: It is possible to declare two different methods in the one class that have the same annotation. Circumstances such as this would cause confusion when a user clicked on an injection point and went to select one of the methods from the generated list, since both would display the same class name only. This bug has been fixed by including the method or field name along with the class name in the generated list.

JBIDE-6445: A bug existed that would cause Eclipse to hang for an unstipulated amount of time when OpenOn for injection points was utilized. This error has now been fixed by modifying the ProducerDisposerHyperlinkDetector, CDIUtil and InjectedPointHyperlinkDetector classes.

JBIDE-6418: When matching injections to CDI injection points, there was occasion when no injections existed or those that did exist were ambiguous, however no feedback was provided to the user indicating this. This has been rectified in this release by adding validation tests for CDI injection points where no matching injections exist or those that match are ambiguous. In these circumstances validation tests will mark these injection points with an error or warning based on user preferences.
JBIDE-6416: A new wizard has been added for easy creation of a Scope Java file. The Scope Annotation Type wizard can be found under the CDI folder in the wizard selection dialog.

JBIDE-6415: A new wizard has been added for easy creation of an Interceptor Binding Java file. The Interceptor Binding Annotation Type wizard can be found under the CDI folder in the wizard selection dialog.
JBIDE-6414: A new wizard has been added for easy creation of a Stereotype Java file. The Stereotype Annotation Type wizard can be found under the CDI folder in the wizard selection dialog.
JBIDE-6413: A new wizard has been added for easy creation of a Qualifier Java file. The Qualifier Annotation Type wizard can be found under the CDI folder in the wizard selection dialog.
JBIDE-6251: OpenOn support has been added for Disposer and Producer methods.

JBIDE-5927: A new feature has been added allowing for CDI @Named annotated beans to be renamed through refactoring. This change appears when using the Find References functionality for EL expressions. The Rename action is available from the context menu for a @Named annotation in the Java Source editor.

JBIDE-3136: A new decorator wizard has been added. To create a new decorator type with the decorator wizard, navigate to FileNewOtherCDIDecorator Type and press Next. The decorator wizard creates a decorator for an existing web bean, and implements @Decorates annotation.

JBIDE-3124: A new feature has been added that allows a user to locate Observer methods for an Event and also locate Event methods for an Observer. To locate the Observer methods for an Event, click on the Open CDI Observer Methods from the content assist menu for an Event. Likewise, select Open CDI Events from the content assist menu for an Observer method to find the relevant Event methods.

JBIDE-3122: A new Interceptor class wizard has been added. To create a new interceptor type with the interceptor wizard, navigate to File New Other CDI Interceptor Type and press Next. The interceptor wizard declares an interceptor for an existing web bean, and implements @Interceptor annotation.
JBIDE-2704: The CDI tool set has been enhanced with code completion added for relevant types and annotations in beans.xml.
JBIDE-6837: Deltacloud tooling has been added for this release.

JBIDE-6459: Functionality has been added that allows a user to right-click on a Fact or POJO and add it to their BRMS or Govnor instance without going through the process of exporting a JAR file and then importing it.

JBIDE-4646: A new wizard is now available that allows for a user to update an existing Drools Guvnor repository connection. Through this wizard a user can update the repository location and security information. To open the wizard, select Edit Connection from the context menu of your connection in the Guvnor Repositories view.

JBIDE-7193: New optional parameters ruleMultithreadEvaluation and ruleMaxThreads have been added to the BussinessRulesProcessor class. ruleMultithreadEvaluation enables or disables KnowledgeBase partitioning. ruleMaxThreads defines the number of threads to use when KnowledgeBase partitioning is enabled. The default values for these parameters is null, disabling them by default.
JBIDE-7235: The ESB validator has been extended to cover the BussinessRulesProcessor class. This ensures that only one ruleSet is specified by the BussinessRulesProcessor, inhibiting conflicts.

JBIDE-7055: Eclipse Helios provides a new view called the Annotation Properties view that is focused on JAXB and JAX-WS annotations. The new view is now extended with support for ESB annotations for action definitions.

To open the new Annotation Properties view, navigate to WindowShow ViewOtherJAX-WSAnnotation Properties and clicking OK. The view can be filtered to display only ESB annotations by selecting the Filters option from the Annotation Properties view menu and then selecting all annotation categories except for JBoss ESB and clicking OK.
JBIDE-6908: Support for ESB 4.9 has been added to the ESB project editor.

JBIDE-6758 and JBIDE-6160: An existing service element without a child security element would not be be able to have the security element added through the user interface. To fix this issue, each service element now has a security element and a subsequent Security form automatically attached in the ESB editor. The security element can safely be deleted from the service element code without the Security form being removed in the ESB editor. This ensures that if a user wishes to re-add a security element at a later stage, the functionality will exist to do so within the user interface.

In fixing this issue the new value of org.jboss.soa.esb.services.security.auth.login.JBossSTSIssueCallbackHandler was also added to the Callback Handler drop-down box. This new value enables the ability to retrieve user and password information from an authentication request.

JBIDE-6616: Support for ESB actions through annotations has been added to the ESB editor. When creating the configuration for a new ESB action, you can now create a new Annotated POJO class as well as a class that extends the AbstractActionPipelinedProcessor class.
JBIDE-6615: ESB 4.9 includes a new router for utilizing the Camel runtime; support for this new router has been added to the ESB tooling.

JBIDE-6614: Support for the new Complex Event Processing (CEP) functionality in ESB 4.9 has been added. The new feature means that CEP can now use the BusinessRulesProcessor action, and this has been added to the ESB tooling.

JBIDE-6609: The ESB Editor did not support the BPELInvoke action, causing error with Riftsaw and ESB integration.To correct this bug the option New BPELInvoke Action is available from the ESB editor's menu when the org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.bpel.BPELInvoke class is apart of the project classpath. This ensures that the BPELInvoke action is only enabled when the Riftsaw runtime is installed.

JBIDE-5551: Language property support has been corrected in the ESB editor. When specifying a ScriptingAction a user can now set a language property instead of allowing the ScriptingAction to determine the language based on the extension of the file.
JBIDE-7092: Support has been added for the Google Web Toolkit (GWT) Designer. To use this functionality do the following:
Install the GWT Designer from http://dl.google.com/eclipse/inst/d2gwt/latest
Create a dynamic web project and active the GWT facet
Build the included GWT examples
Right-click on Gwt_jboss.java and choose Open withWindowBuilder Editor from the menu
Switch the editor to the Designer tab

JBIDE-6988: Console configuration would not take into account the schema and catalog being specified for a JPA project. This meant that if two schemas existed for one database when a user opened the created console configuration, it would error indicating there was two database schemas. The expected result is that the schema that has been set for the project would be used.

Expected behavior has been implemented by setting a default_schema property in the properties for the project as if this was being set in the hibernate.properties file. However properties in the hibernate.properties file will overwrite project properties.
JBIDE-6974: Support for comments in the HQL editor has been added for this release. Comments are annotated with -- at the beginning of each comment line.

JBIDE-6727: When a JPA project is created with Hibernate a console configuration is automatically created for it. However if a Hibernate JPA project did not have a console configuration associated with it an exception would occur due to the tooling assuming a console configuration existed. To avoid this situation, Hibernate JPA projects are now tested for an associated console configuration. If a console configuration is not found an error will appear in the Problems view.

JBIDE-6703: The QueryExporter has been added to the exporters for use in Hibernate code generation configurations. This is accomplished by allowing all Ant export tasks to be executed from the user interface.

JBIDE-6686: An error existed where the Hibernate platform to be used was not filtered based on the version of JPA being used. This meant that selecting the JPA version to use would present all Hibernate platforms to the user, with indistinct names. This issue has been corrected by only displaying the Hibernate platform that corresponds to the specified JPA version, and renaming these platforms for easier identification.

JBIDE-6621: In previous versions, when a user selected Ingres from the list of databases or database dialects the Driver Name and Connection URL fields would not be auto-populated as they are for other databases in the list. This has lead to concerns of the compatibility of Ingres with JBoss Enterprise Application Platform. To correct this issue the new Ingres dialects Ingres9Dialect and Ingres10Dialect have been added, ensuring the aforementioned fields are auto-populated for both versions 9 and 10 of Hibernate core.

JBIDE-6518: A new feature has been added that makes it possible to export a Hibernate code generation configuration to an Ant build file. To use this feature navigate to FileExportHibernateAnt Code Generation.
JBIDE-6473: A new Hibernate platform has been added called Hibernate JPA 2.0. This platform extends the base JPA 2.0 platform.

JBIDE-6423: A new feature that allows for code generation to be run in external processes has been added. This new feature is accessed through the Hibernate Code Generation Configurations wizard in the form of a checkbox called Use generation in external process.

JBIDE-6120: Superclass properties were not shown in code completion, within the HQLEditor. A new feature has been added for this release that enables superclass properties to appear when using code completion within the HQLEditor.

JBIDE-6115: The Schema Export (.ddl) exporter would apply any changes made by a user to the database during the export process. This was unexpected behavior and had the ability to cause unwanted data loss. This issue has been corrected by ensuring that the script is not exported to the database by default, thus no changes are applied to the database by default now when using the Schema Export (.ddl) functionality.

JBIDE-5847: New functionality has been added that allows for Dali 2.3 support in Hibernate Tools. Dali 2.3 is the latest release of the Eclipse Web Tools Platform, part of the larger Eclipse Helios release that this JBoss release is built upon.

JBIDE-5805: Usability has been improved with this release by including matching bracket highlighting within the Hibernate Query Language (HQL) editor. When a user has the cursor beside a bracket in their code, the paired bracket will be highlighted. This functionality is useful for debuging applications.
JBIDE-5411: Packages without Java classes are now correctly filtered from being shown in the New Hibernate hbm.xml wizard. This wizard is used to create a new Hibernate XML mapping file.
JBIDE-4663: @DiscriminatorFormula annotation has been fixed so that the assigned value appears in the Formula field of the JPA Details tab.

JBIDE-4202: In previous releases a user was not able to enter a parameter list using the Hibernate Query Editor. For this release the Query Parameters view has been improved to allow a user to select a parameter type from a list, if more than one parameter exists. To achieve this a user can click on the ... button in the Value field of the Query Parameters view. If the button does not appear then there is only one parameter available.

JBIDE-6104: An error existed that meant local and deployment server settings were not saved and upon reopening the jBPM Process Definition Language (JPDL) all the settings would need to be reconfigured. With this release changes made to local and deployment server settings are made persistent across JPDL sessions.

JBIDE-5911: Previously it was only possible to have one jBPM process definition in a package (folder). Support has been added in this version that allows for multiple process definitions to exist in the one package.

JBIDE-7439: Code completion has been added for the name attribute based on the associated type. For example: Code completion is now available for <cc:attribute name="myattr" type="java.lang.String" />.
JBIDE-7433 and JBIDE-7424: Palette tools have been added to the JSF tooling that support RichFaces 4.0.
JBIDE-7422: Templates have been created and are included that combine JSF 2.0 and RichFaces 4.0.

JBIDE-7265 and JBIDE-7264: Refactoring speed has been improved. Previously when a user would perform a refactoring action, every Expression Language (EL) parameter would be checked, even if the Java class was not used in an Expression Language. Speed has been improved for this release by containing EL parameter checking to only those of relevance; this is achieved by using the ValidationContext class.

JBIDE-7147: The validators create a marker for each problem found when conducting validation. An issue would arise where system performance would be dramatically decreased when an excessive amount of problems were discovered and subsequently marked. To ensure a system does not receive a performance hit, the Validator preferences screen now includes the ability to set the maximum number of problems reported per file. If there are more issues in a file than the maximum number to be reported, once the reported issues are corrected the others will be reported in subsequent validation attempts.

JBIDE-7086: MyFaces uses the library myfaces-metadata.xml to enable tag auto-completion, a plug-in that was not supported. MyFaces plug-in library support has been added, allowing for MyFaces tag auto-completion.

JBIDE-7021: Low performance issues existed for validation of web pages. Performance issues were caused by the XHTML syntax validator performing to slow if a DOCTYPE was not declared at the top of XHTML files, the PageContextFactory.createPageContext method created a SSE model for non-facelet pages, if a page contained Expression Language (EL) errors or warnings, a memory leak appeared in the PageContextFactory.getSheetForTagAttribute method by registering ExtendedLinkElementAdapter and never releasing the memory allocated to it. These issues have been addressed in this release and the PageContextFactory class has been removed from the resource listeners since resources can be modified without changing their context in other places apart from the included validators.
JBIDE-6816: A template page for RichFaces has been added to the list of available XHTML templates.
JBIDE-6815: A template page has been added that does not incorporate Facelets.

JBIDE-6732: New functionality has been added that allows a user to refactor a JSF 2 composite components directory. This means that a user can rename the directory and every reference to the folder within namespace definitions of web pages will be updated accordingly, through the refactoring process.

JBIDE-6285: Previously when a user would insert a start and ending tag (for example, <tag><tag>), code assistance would turn on when the cursor was placed between the tags. This behavior was not an assistance to the user under normal circumstances as when a user pressed the Enter key, to separate the tags, the first code assist proposal would be inserted instead. For this release Code assistance has been improved by realizing that in the mentioned circumstance no assistance is required.
JBIDE-6276: The ability to preview refactoring changes made to JSF 2 components has been added.
JBIDE-6266: Content Assist now includes support for Web Standards Tools (WST) categories. A further two categories have been added: JBoss JSF/Seam EL and JBoss JSF/Seam Tag Proposals.
JBIDE-6259 and JBIDE-6025: A new option has been added to the Preferences page allowing a user to enable or disable code assist of get and set methods in the expression language.
JBIDE-5946: A new XHTML template called JSF Composite Component has been added to the new XHTML page wizard that assists in the creation of JSF2 composite components.

JBIDE-5943: The possibility to rename a JSF component attribute name now exists. To rename a component name right-click on the name in your XHTML editor and navigate to RefactorRename and input a new name in the Rename Composite Attribute dialog.

JBIDE-5942: The ability to refactor a JSF component has been added. This allows for a user to change the name of a component file and for this change to persist in the project the component is a part of.
JBIDE-5941: Content assist support has been added for composite attributes. To support this functionality the JSF2CCAttrsELCompletionEngine class has been added.
JBIDE-5937: If a custom element attribute does not exist then a user can perform a quick fix to create it.

JBIDE-5930: When creating a custom JSF2 page and a coded element name does not exist, the user will be presented with a quick fix option. To select the quick fix option navigate to the Problems window where the Warnings information appears and rick-click on the warning specifying that the element name does not exist. From the displayed menu, navigate to Quick Fix. The Quick Fix dialog will then display with a list of fixes for the problem. Select one from the list and click Finish to apply the quick fix.

JBIDE-5922: When referencing a resource that does not exist (for example, having the following code at the top of a HTML page xmlns:newResource="http://java.sun.com/jsf/composite/newResource"), the user can now select the Quick Fix option from the context menu that will create a folder for this resource under the resources folder for your project.

JBIDE-5888: The Add JSF Capabilities wizard has been updated to support the new Servlet 3.0 standard. A user can select to use Servlet 3.0 from the Servlet Version drop-down list on the Project Folders page of the wizard.
JBIDE-5677: JSF 2 is now supported for web projects. When a user is configuring Project Facets and selects to add JSF support, JSF 2 is now an available option.
JBIDE-5219: The JSF 2 kick start project template has been added and is now available within the New JSF Project Wizard.

JBIDE-4990: When performing an Expression Language (EL) variable refactoring (renaming), all occurrences of the specific variable are renamed accordingly. The refactoring action is available from the context menu of an Expression Language (EL) variable in the JSP and XHTML editors.

JBIDE-4947: A new feature has been added that produces a tool tip for any Expression Language (EL) element that a user hovers the mouse cursor over. The tool tip displays information about the EL element.

JBIDE-4876: The quick fix operation has been enhanced, now offering to add the corresponding tag library definition to the JSP or XHTML header for any tags without a corresponding XML Namespace (XMLNS) in the document header.

JBIDE-6973: A HTTP poller has been added for JBoss servers to detect if the server is running. This added feature will be useful for remote and local servers, being less resource-intensive than polling with JMX.

JBIDE-6796: Launch configuration of the server can now be altered to perform different tasks based on the server mode; sample modes include local and Remote System Explorer (RSE). This added functionality has been achieved by separating launch behavior into separate classes.
JBIDE-6707: The ability to Explore a specific resource on a server has now been expanded to encapsulate the entire server, allowing the deploy directory to be explored.

JBIDE-6612: The new version of Eclipse would not recognize JBoss Application Server 6 as a valid JEE6 environment. To rectify this bug, Java EE6 has been configured to support JBoss Application Server 6 by modifying /as/plugins/org.jboss.ide.eclipse.as.core/plugin.xml .

JBIDE-5109: JBoss Application Server tooling as been improved to now allow regular JBoss servers to use remote deployment instead of just SSH Server deployment. Previously remote deployment was only available to JBoss EC2 servers, and not regular remote hosts.

JBIDE-7245 and JBIDE-6360:Previously only view-id entries in the redirect tag were checked for validity. Error checking for this parameter has been extended to include occurrences of the attribute within all tags.

JBIDE-6877 and JBIDE-6875: When a user writes code for the Seam component that won't compile, new quick fixes are now presented through annotations. Quick fixes include the ability to quickly add a Name annotation to the class and delete a Create, Unwrap or Observer annotation from the method.
JBIDE-6876: The quick fix annotation suggestions for the Destroy method have been updated to remove Set Seam properties option. This option should not have been presented in this situation.
JBIDE-6874: Quick fix now offers to delete any Remove annotation.
JBIDE-6873 and JBIDE-6871: For Scope annotation, quick fix now offers to change a component's scope.
JBIDE-6872: Quick fix has added functionality that offers to create setter and getter methods for component class property if the methods do not exist.
JBIDE-6870: Quick fix now offers to create a new method with Remove or Destroy annotation. These annotations are also offered as additions to existing methods.
JBIDE-6869: Quick fix now offers to rename a component if it is a duplicate and to delete Name annotation.

JBIDE-6610: Components defined in a custom component.xml file were not recognized. This bug has been corrected through the modification of XMLScanner.java, SeamComponentsEntityRecognizer.java and SeamResourceVisitor.java.
JBIDE-5231 and JBIDE-5198: Content assist has been improved to suggest attributes of Seam PDF and Seam mail components to the user, when appropriate.

JBIDE-5134: When implementing a Quick Fix from the context menu of a Seam Runtime NAME does not exist error the Name and Version fields are now automatically filled in. The name field is editable in case a runtime already exists with the generated name, however the version is locked to the version used in the Seam project settings.

JBIDE-5007: When using the Generate Seam Entities wizard, the option to Use existing reveng file has been added. Once this checkbox has been checked, a user can use the Browse button beside the reveng.xml field to navigate to the existing file. By importing a NAME.reveng.xml file a user can regenerate the entities for use in the new Seam project.
JBIDE-4064: Numerious Quick Fix operations within the Seam tooling have been improved. These improvements are detailed within this Seam section of the release notes.

JBIDE-2809: A new feature has been added to the New Seam Project wizard. The wizard now allows a user to specify unique names for each project deployment type of WAR, EJB and EAR. This means that the one project can now be named differently depending on the deployment type.
JBIDE-7434: Templates with support for RichFaces 4.0 have been added to the Visual Page Editor.

JBIDE-7383: When using the Visual Page Editor (VPE), a new option has been introduced that allows a user to select where the editor toolbar icons should be displayed. The icons can now be displayed either as part of the general VPE toolbar or as part of the main Eclipse toolbar. To choose between these options navigate to WindowPreferencesJBoss ToolsWebEditorsVisual Page Editor. By default the editor icons are included as part of the main Eclipse toolbar.

JBIDE-7059: XulRunner (XR) has become an optional install of the Visual Page Editor. This decision has meant that the buttons of the Visual Page Editor plug-in have been moved to be apart of the Eclipse icon bar.

JBIDE-6981: Functionality has been added that provides a drop-down menu in the tag breadcrumbs that enables easy selection of any child element to the selected tag. If there are no children to be expanded, the last tag will remain highlighted.
JBIDE-6805: New templates have been added, supporting most docbook tags.
JBIDE-6721 and JBIDE-6711: Spring support has been added to the Visual Page Editor through the addition of a new plug-in. The plug-in is available as org.jboss.tools.vpe.spring.

JBIDE-6631: Previously the only way to export a template was by navigating to FileExportUnknown. This process was not intuitive and so Import and Export buttons have been added to the Visual Templates Preferences page. Due to Java prohibiting the extension of more than one class, extra classes have been written for this added functionality.

JBIDE-6600: The Visual Page Editor would use all available template libraries regardless of the opened content. This caused conflicts between templates; an example of this is the head tag appearing in both the docbook and HTML templates. The solution has been to create a separate editor for docbook.
JBIDE-6385: The icon for the Externalize Strings action in the Visual Page Editor toolbar has been updated.
JBIDE-6333: When resizing an image, a caption now appears at the users cursor to indicate the current size an image will be resized to.

JBIDE-6288: When hovering over a button created in the Visual Page Editor, the button would not be highlighted on Linux operating systems. This issue has been corrected by modifying the following files: VpeController.java, VpeDnD.java, MozillaEventAdapter.java, VisualDomUtil.java and MozillaDndListener.java.
JBIDE-6114: A new template has been added to the Visual Page Editor, enabling improved rendering of the jBPM task forms.

JBIDE-6092: New features have been added to the Visual Page Editor that allow for items in a table to be moved by select CSS classes and for all items in a CSS tree node to be moved through the CSS class viewer.
JBIDE-5970: A new feature has been added that indicates the drop actions available to a user while they are dragging an element. Available actions are displayed to the user in a text caption.

JBIDE-5101: A bug existed within the resizer tool, which meant that it was not shown correctly for buttons, input fields and controls. This readability and usability issue has been resolved by adjusting the padding for the body of a Visual Page Editor page, allowing space for resizer elements.
JBIDE-5042: Drag and drop actions have been improved to be more reliable and easier to use. The list of improvements is as follows:
The drop indicator is now shown in all drop locations available
The four arrow resize icon is shown for any selected element that is draggable
The drop container is now highlighted blue, making it easier to see what the result of a drop action will be
When an element is being dragged, an image of the element appears under the mouse cursor
Drop targets of any move event are marked by sold black lines that may appear before or after any other object
The current drop target is highlighted red
JBIDE-3875: Content assist has been added for the facet name tag.The content assist for this tag is based on the metadata of the parent JSF tag.

JBIDE-3288: The CSS class wizard user interface has been improved. Improvements include a new Preview view that allows a user to observe the selected CSS class and real-time alterations and a file tree panel for easy class selection.
JBIDE-2795: A new feature has been added that allows templates created using the Visual Page Editor to be exported to a file. This functionality is useful for sharing custom templates between users.
JBIDE-7106: Annotations have been added for JAX-RS (Java API for RESTful Web Services). This addition has been accomplished by modifying the Annotation Properties view.

JBIDE-6904: A new wizard is available for creating JAX-WS and JAX-RS services from annotated class files. If the classes do not exist upon creation of the services, they will be created during service creation, the same as if the user had used the Create a Sample Web Service or Create a Sample RESTful Web Service wizards.

JBIDE-6851 and JBIDE-6850: A new feature has been added providing the ability to read Web Service Definition Language (WSDL) over HTTPS. This ensures that secured GET and POST methods are usable and will not produce a com.sun.xml.internal.ws.wsdl.parser.InaccessibleWSDLException: 2 counts of InaccessibleWSDLException exception.

JBIDE-6797: A new Options menu item has been added to the Web Services interface for JAX-RS. The Options menu item allows a user to test RESTful web services for allowed HTTP methods such as POST and GET. Results from the Options operation are viewable in the Response Headers list.

JBIDE-6753: In JBoss Application Server 6 no entries are required in the web.xml file, however entries remain mandatory for earlier releases. To reflect this upgrade, the Generate a Sample RESTful Web Service wizard now contains a checkbox to Update web.xml. By default the update option is enabled. If a user is aware that JBoss Application Server 6 is being utilized and they do not wish to update the web.xml file, this checkbox can be unchecked.

JBIDE-6660: A bug existed in the Web Services tooling such that when a user attempted to connect with a password protected URL (for example, a deltacloud) a dialog would appear requesting a username and password combination, however when the information was submitted it would not persist; this ensured the user would be asked for login details continually. This issue has been fixed by the creation of a new dialog that remembers the authentication information last used, however login information is not currently persisted between sessions (for example, closing and then reopening a workbench).
JBIDE-6589: In previous releases a JAX-WS invocation could not be canceled. Support for canceling a long-running invocation has been implemented and improved for this release.

JBIDE-5723: A new wizard has been added called Create a Sample Web Service. This wizard allows a user to get a web service up and running quickly. The wizard adds the RestEasy code to the web.xml file, creates the application class and JAX-RS annotated resource class, and adds the required RestEast JAR files from the runtime. Once created, the new web service project can be tested using the Web Service Tester.
JBIDE-5975: The web.xml editor did not support the JavaEE 6 Servlet 3.0 specification. The web.xml editor has now been updated to support the new Servlet specification version.

JBIDE-7393: The search functionality has been upgraded for the tooling set. This upgrade now allows a user to search using the special characters * and \, for any string and any character respectively. To perform a literal search for these characters, append a \ following the character in the search parameter.

JBIDE-6507: Support has been added for enabling and disabling project validators based on the JBoss KB (Knowledge Base) project validator. Validators that can be enabled or disabled include those for JSF, Seam and CDI.

JBIDE-6238: When a user accesses example projects some of the sites used by the examples may not be reachable due to no network access, proxy or firewall settings. Previously the user would not be informed of this issue. In this release the user is now informed when a site attempting to be accessed by an example project is unreachable.
JBIDE-6183: Library files for RichFaces have been updated to the latest version, supporting RichFaces 3.3.3.

JBIDE-6131: Previously the specification of XHTML templates was handled by navigating to WindowPreferencesJBoss ToolsJSFJSF Pages. This process was not intuitive for users as the standard Eclipse method of specifying templates is by navigating to WindowPreferencesCOMPONENT_NAMEEditorTemplates. Specification of XHTML templates is now handled using the standard Eclipse user interface approach, improving usability.

JBIDE-6119: When installing the tool set, the included installer has the ability to find, detect and configure JBoss server runtimes for use; this functionality however was never extended past the initial installation. A new feature has been added that now allows a user to find, detect and configure installed JBoss server runtimes after installation. This new functionality can be found by navigating to WindowPreferencesJBoss ToolsJBoss Runtimes.

JBIDE-6083: Functionality has been added to all editors that allow for them to be placed vertically side by side, rather than just horizontally. This new feature is available through the Window menu of Eclipse.

JBIDE-5950: Additional runtime checks have been added to the ESB and BPEL project examples. This ensures that the ability to specify required components is available, as it is for other project examples.

JBIDE-4858: A new feature has been added that allows for message bundles to be refactored from within the JSF and Seam editors. To refactor messages from within the JSF editor, highlight the message and select EL Refactor from the context menu. Refactoring messages from within the Seam editor is accomplished by selecting the message through the Package Explorer and navigating to Refactor from the context menu.
